title: Martha Wainwright - Come Home To Mama [2012] [FLAC]
description:

02. Can You Believe It
03. Radio Star
04. Proserpina
05. Leave Behind
06. Four Black Sheep
07. Some People
08. I Wanna Make An Arrest
09. All Your Clothes

13. Four Black Sheep (Demo)

The Wainright-McGarrigles are the family that just keep giving. And given the mainstream appeal of brother RufusÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ most recent album Out of the Game and this fourth album from Martha, they want to give to as many folk as possible.
Much has changed chez Martha in recent years Ã¢â‚¬â€œ marriage, motherhood and the death of her mother Kate McGarrigle. The fury of her attention-seeking Bloody Mother F***ing Asshole ballad and the pain of the album I Know You're Married But I've Got Feelings Too have been moulded and tempered.
This process of growing up began on the 2009 live album Sans Fusils, Ni Souliers, ÃƒÂ  Paris: Martha Wainwright's Piaf Record, and now Come Home to Mama. The album is almost shockingly great. MarthaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Piaf-like stab at emotional rollercoaster torch song is well documented, but not this level of subtlety and control.
This might well be down to working this time with another woman, Yuka C Honda (the instrumental half of New York-based Japanese duo Cibo Matto) instead of WainwrightÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s producer/husband Brad Albetta, whose programming/producing touch shapes the albumÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s warm, intimate, expansive slopes.
Come Home to Mama is not limited to any folk, torch or soul source, nor an overtly 1970s brief like Out of the Game; it sounds singularly out on its own, likewise WainwrightÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s voice. Even when sheÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s emoting ecstatically on Some People, it doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t resemble the protesting or sometimes exhausting figure of MarthaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s past.
Motherhood has a lot to answer for. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not a direct musical comparison but, recorded after Elizabeth FraserÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s first baby, Cocteau TwinsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ album Heaven or Las Vegas was bathed in a potent, golden glow, and thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s how Come Home to Mama feels. The Fraser-like touches of I Am Sorry and All Your Clothes are perhaps incidental, and the Al Green mood of Can You Believe It, the slinky pop provocation of Radio Star and the torchy lullaby of Proserpina, written by her mother, are certainly far from ethereal la-la land.
This is more Laura Nyro, Barbra Streisand (hear Leave Behind), Phoebe SnowÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ or, rather, more Martha Wainwright. Who here has realised her best record to date.
